importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the raid on KK Park, highlighting the timing of military action against scam operations in a volatile region.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The broader context of Myanmar's civil war since 2021, including the military's crackdown on criminal networks and opposition groups.

keyTakeAways: Myanmar's military arrested over 2,198 people, including 445 women and 1,645 men, in a raid on KK Park, a notorious scam centre on the Thai border.

KK Park, located in Myawaddy Township, Kayin State, spans over 250 low-rise buildings and is linked to illegal gambling, money laundering, and online scams involving international criminal syndicates.
The military seized 30 Starlink satellites—operated by SpaceX and Elon Musk—used to maintain internet connectivity in the scam operations.
Senior leaders of the Karen National Union (KNU), a key armed opposition group, are reportedly involved in scam activities at KK Park, linking military operations to political opposition.
Scam operations have drawn Chinese criminal syndicates and human trafficking networks, with Thai police estimating up to 100,000 people working in border-based scams.
The issue has drawn international attention, especially after Chinese actor Wang Xing was trafficked and rescued in January 2025, increasing pressure on Thailand and China to act.
The U.S. Department of the Treasury sanctioned over 20 entities and individuals in Myanmar and Cambodia linked to scam operations in September 2025.
Employees of scam centres are often victims of human trafficking, lured by false employment promises and forced into slave-like scam work.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In a major military operation on October 21, 2025, Myanmar’s armed forces arrested over 2,198 people, including 445 women and 1,645 men, at KK Park—a notorious scam centre in Myawaddy Township, Kayin State, near the Thai border. The site, spanning over 250 low-rise buildings, has long been used by international criminal syndicates for illegal gambling, money laundering, and online romance and investment scams. The military seized 30 Starlink satellites, which are used to maintain internet connectivity for scam operations. The raid reportedly targeted top leaders of the Karen National Union, linking armed conflict with criminal enterprises. The operation comes amid growing international pressure from Thailand and China, especially after Chinese actor Wang Xing was trafficked and rescued in January 2025. Human rights groups warn that many employees are victims of trafficking, lured by false job promises and forced into slave-like conditions. The U.S. Department of the Treasury has also sanctioned over 20 individuals and companies in Myanmar and Cambodia linked to scam operations, underscoring the global scale and severity of the issue.
title: Myanmar military arrests more than 2,000 people at infamous scam centre
